The first Toy Soldiers is one of my all time favorite games. The fact that this has the original Toy Soldiers and all of its DLC AND the second Toy Soldier and all of ITS DLC for $10 is amazing. At the time of writing this review I have 1.6 hours clocked in and have barley worked through the first campaign of the Cold War part, this pack gives you a lot of bang for your buck.

I grew up playing countless tower defense flash games and this game is by far the best in the tower defense genre I have played. The selling-point mechanic that sets this game apart from other tower defense games is that you can take control of your various towers and vehicles on the map to fight the waves of enemies head on. While controlling a tower the game will give it bonus abilities, for example an AI mortar tower will fire one round then aim and fire again; when the play controls that same tower they can now fire three mortars in quick succession or take control of one fired shell, altering its course slightly and speed dramatically. However you can play the entire game without touching a vehicle or controlling a tower and play it as any other tower defense game, the vehicles and tower control will just give you that extra edge when things get tense and enemies slip through the lines.

This game is beautifully themed and designed, all the soldiers, vehicles, towers, and environments are in the style of an old war diorama model kit. The vehicles are all wind up, the soldiers are all display figures, the towers are all little glued together models, and the maps all take place in open model terrain cases, complete with painted cardboard sky and cloud borders on maps that give you a plane.

One of my favorite parts of the game is the ability to pause it at any time and enter Tilt-Shift mode" which brings the depth of field and focal point really close up and drops the camera to near the ground so you can take some awesome screenshots

Early Access Review

Toy Soldiers: Complete is in early access, so at the present time only Cold War is available to play. Keep that in mind for the review, but if it's any consolation, I've also played both on Xbox 360.

Toy Soldiers is a tower defense game where the player can control turrets to take more control (or use special turret functions), use vehicles or call powers down upon the enemy. This is the all-inclusive Toy Soldiers package; both games and all of the DLC are included. Toy Soldiers is World War I themed while Cold War is 80's action movie interpretations of the cold war.

The game is easy to jump in to. The only thing to keep in mind is that turrets sometimes change a lot when upgrading. For example: level 2 anti-tank turrets lose their shell cams, which is useful for targeting long distance enemies. The rest is simple: defend your toy box (base) from enemies.

There's a campaign mode and two mini campaigns (previously DLC) along with versus, survival and minigames. The game also supports coop, but I haven't tried it on PC yet. Toy Soldiers has plenty to offer at the moment, as it's well polished, funny and most of all: fun. In it's current state it's well worth $10, but once it make it out of early access (and includes the original Toy Soldiers) it'll be a steal.

Toy Soliders Complete is the original Toy Soldiers tower defense game along with its 2 expansions and the Cold War stand-alone with it's two expansions.

- You can place turrets in specific locations. Certain turrets (like ani-air and artillery) require larger spaces. Upgrade turrets and fend off the invading forces.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What an awful game, it has potential to be very good, but there are a lot of buggy concepts that badly let it down.

In the first game WWI, on the level 10 of the 3rd mission, the final 2 wheeled large gun carriage thingumy simply sinks into the map never to be seen again, preventing completion of the map. No amount of reloading or replaying the map will stop it from sinking into the map. This particular defect has been outstanding for at least a couple of months.

The AI is fairly useless, for example in Cold War series, on the map where you have helicopters flying in, the biggest suite of defects is that the Tank Destroyer AI turrets will not fire at anything that is not on your side of the map, refusing to fire at anything on the Soviet side of the map, unless you are personally controlling them. What makes it a real challenge is the fact that you are revealed to have two HQs, one on the Soviet side of the map (what should be the Soviet toybox is actually your 2nd toybox), that you can't properly defend (because surprise surprise you can't put turrets on the Soviet side to defend it). So one set of enemy tanks start on the Soviet side and then stream into your Soviet-side HQ and the rest of the vehicles/ tanks stream into the actual US HQ (toy box) on your side of the map. So because you have 2 HQs, you lose the scenario even faster. Oh yes and the 2nd Soviet Anti-Aircraft battery that you are meant to destroy is also missing.

In this particular scenario, when left to the AI, not enough cash is racked up to aid with selling battery emplacements to allow you to buy anti-aircraft (armoured Soviet helicopters) batteries (and you need at least 4, or 2 upgraded with you controlling one) to defeat the helicopters. Of course then you have virtually no funds left to sell the anti-aircraft batteries and replace them with machine-gun batteries to defend vs the final level.

The other major defect is not being able to freely scroll over the map, you are forced to select an battery emplacement and use it to bug out and select another battery to move over the battlefield. Trying to scroll or move the view to see another battery and the game simply prevents you from doing anything. You are stuck in a corner or a useless part of the map, unable to scroll or move your focus.

This game is far from Complete, more like Alpha test with a LOT of outstanding basic game handling concepts yet to be resolved.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't get me wrong: I love Toy Soldiers. It's the only tower defence game I like, and it has cool and fun mechanics, namely that you can control the towers directly if you choose. Vehicles and the like are also present in Cold War. But Toy Soldiers: Complete is terrible.

You could say it's the same game, sure, it's a collection of the 2 and DLC, but it's not. The controlls are horrendous. Honestly, aiming should be keyboard only. The mouse is awful for anything. Know when you play a game and your mouse moves faster on the X-Axis (Left and right) than it can on the Y? It's like that. Times eleven. Shell cam, one of my favorite features, allows you to move and aim your shells, rockets and missiles and speed or slow them up in mid-air. Not slow or fast motion, actually hold the shell almost still waiting for your target to come closer to where you aimed. You have to use WASD, the camera controls. Also the controls that switch fast between turrets. It initiates that when you try to use Shell cam. On the coin of turrets, some levels start you in one. When they do, and I recommend using a controller anytime for this game. The use of a controller stops all of these bugs in their tracks but the following. When you start in a turret, you have your mouse in the center of the screen, the crosshair. Know bad indie games that don't have down the knack of not showing your cursor during gameplay? That element isn't here. You get to see your mouse. To get rid of it, you have to exit then reenter your turret.

Difficulty spikes absolutely insanely. The first level of Evil Empire, my favorite campaign because it gives you a break from constant US crap that goes on for a whole campaign plus one pack of DLC, you get new equipment, turrets and vehicles to use, is impossible. And when I say impossible, I don't mean it's not possible as in it's hard. It's impossible to complete. You start with an infantry fighting vehicle, IFV, you've got a rocket launcher with slow reload times and a large millimeter gun. You clearly should take out the 2 enemy turrets ahead of you. Fantastic. You have 10 thousand dollars, a lot of money for equipment. And there's a jet flying around. You can see how many enemies are there, that's the thing, remember that. It bombs you constantly, and you clearly need to build an anti-air emplacement. Fantastic. When you do that, you think the bombs stop. For 10 seconds. Then the next wave comes and soldiers go through. I swear to whatever powers that be, that control existence that their damage is multiplied by 100. I've had level 3, top teir turrets be killed with full health by 1- ONE soldier's gunfire. One shot of that gunfire. And there's still bombs. After 10 seconds, more bombs drop which instantly kill your emplacements. And there's no jets. Neither my eyesight nor the enemy counter displays jets, but you still get constantly bombed. Unstoppably bombed.

Then it drops. The first level of the other DLC, you get barrages, Cold War game's power-ups for killing a lot of troops fast (Which are preceded by overkill boosts. They give you infinite ammo once you get to about 75% of a meter at the bottom left, at 100% you get a barrage) that reward you with nuclear strikes, a commando, bombing runs, et cetera. First level of USA's DLC, you get a barrage every 10 seconds. I got one 8 times  first time I tried it. Then back to normal.

I hope these issues will be fixed. TS is a good game, it's fantastic and I really was happy to see it here. I was skeptical at early access
date: and rightfully so. I'll play it, sure, (It being Cold War, the sequel. Original WWI TS is absent as of yet, coming soon) and like it, but don't. Don't get it yourself until it's further complete. And bring a controller just in case. When it's out, get it, by all means GET IT! It's an amazing game, the omnibus version is just mediocre. Wait for it to be out in full, no more early access. That's my advice.\n\nEDIT: Oh, I forgot to mention. The HUD is wonky with croshairs appearing off the edge, or even not on the screen at all, and your mouse is always there. It resets it's position. Chaning resolution keeps low-res HUD parts, such as the crosshair and pictures on the wave meter. 1366x768 resolution is upside down. Again, wait for it to be released in full.
